report_title: Mental Health & Substance Abuse Clinics in the US
executive_summary: Rising awareness of the economic, personal and societal benefits of mental health and substance abuse treatment has supported the development of mental health and substance abuse clinics. Outpatient clinics' expansion has been vital, as growing rates of mental illness and a worsening opioid epidemic bolster the need for comprehensive treatment. Rising incomes and broader insurance coverage have also facilitated treatment access in recent years. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the extent of the mental health crisis in the US, straining an already overburdened industry. Federal funding helped clinics survive the pandemic, but inflation, workforce shortages and an evolving regulatory environment are challenging outpatient providers even as the need for outpatient treatment climbs to an all-time high. current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Waning Stigma Strengthens Outpatient Mental Health Providers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Destigmatization and growing acceptance of the societal, personal and economic benefits of comprehensive mental illness and substance abuse treatment have been supporting the industry's growth in recent years. Since the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equality Act was enacted in 2008, broader insurance coverage of behavioral healthcare has also provided outpatient clinics with larger patient populations actively seeking care.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Outpatient Clinics Continue to Navigate the Pandemic's Impacts
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic introduced financial and operational challenges to mental health and substance abuse clinics. Outpatient mental health clinics were better suited to shift than inpatient ones, but sudden adjustments to patient volumes, workflows and safety protocols created unprecedented disruption. Relief funding kept clinics operating throughout the pandemic, preventing revenue loss. Telemedicine adoption also allowed outpatient providers to maintain patient care.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Challenging Labor Market Pressures the Outpatient Space
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The greatest obstacle facing outpatient clinics is an undersized behavioral health workforce. Outpatient mental health providers were already strained pre-COVID, but an exodus of healthcare workers during the pandemic coupled with high rates of burnout and turnover have worsened the situation. A complex reimbursement environment, an aging workforce and low starting salaries contribute to shortages.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Outpatient Mental Health Treatment is Ripe for Consolidation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fragmentation creates steep competition between outpatient providers – consolidation provides an outlet to strengthen their position by expanding their geographic reach, increasing capacity and introducing new service offerings. A deepening mental health and overdose crisis in the US bolsters the role of outpatient clinics in the continuum of care – an expanding role has introduced private equity (PE) investment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for Mental Health Treatment Will Stay at All-Time High Post-COVID
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic increased the prevalence of mental illness in the US, yet clinics struggled to treat new patients, creating a greater unmet need for mental health. The unmet need for mental health treatment will continue pouring over into clinics moving forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Psychiatrist Shortages Will Escalate as Demand Outpaces Capacity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Chronic shortages in the mental health care workforce pre-COVID will be more extreme moving forward, as the number of individuals seeking care for mental illness will outpace psychiatrists' ability to deliver care.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Telehealth and Private Equity Offer Alternative Solutions to Shortages
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Telehealth isn't new but surged in popularity during the pandemic. Telehealth tools allowed clinics to meet with patients virtually during the pandemic and will continue to have a pivotal role in treatment delivery. Yet, rapidly expanding telehealth apps could siphon patients away from clinics and onto their phones. Private equity (PE) firms are slated to continue pouring billions of dollars into the mental health space despite higher borrowing costs.

industry_definition: Mental health and substance abuse clinics are medical facilities providing outpatient treatment for individuals facing challenges related to mental health issues or substance abuse.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: The pandemic deepened a mental health crisis. Unprecedented rates of mental illness and an opioid crisis are straining the infrastructure of outpatient mental health clinics nationwide. An undersized behavioral health workforce stymies expansion. Accelerating demand for mental health and substance abuse treatment is outpacing strained clinics' ability to deliver care.

The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration allocates billions in funding to mental health and substance abuse clinics annually. SAMHSA grants promote access to mental health services or directly fund the development of mental health clinics, the workforce and services.
Mental health and substance abuse clinics face extensive regulations at the federal and state level. A complex regulatory environment dictates how, where and to what extent clinics can operate.
Medicaid is the single largest payer of mental health services. Mental health clinics rely on Medicaid reimbursements more than any other revenue source.

Pandemic stressors exacerbated preexisting mental health conditions, creating a greater need for comprehensive mental health treatment. Mental health clinics have struggled to meet the elevated demand for mental health care.

Mental health clinics focus on metropolitan areas. Metro areas have larger patient pools, larger concentrations of mental health providers and high reported rates of mental illness and substance abuse.
Population hubs support mental health clinics. The Southeast and West have the largest populations, warranting a greater need for mental health and substance abuse clinics.
Clinical outcomes measure treatment success. Patients and their families seek out clinics with established histories of patient success stories.
Insurance limitations create steep out-of-pocket costs. Patients will choose a clinic that offers the best balance of out-of-pocket expenses and quality.

Mental health care delivery is fragmented. Mental health and substance abuse clinics are developed to serve local areas based on the level of need in the area, limiting any one clinic from developing a foothold.

Wages have quickly jumped to over half of revenue. While pandemic-era trends driving wage growth are settling, nationwide shortages of psychiatrists and nonclinical staff pressure clinics to pay more than ever for labor.
Operational challenges hit profit growth. A mix of mounting regulatory costs, wage expenses and inflation has weakened the average industry profit margin in recent years.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: COVID-19 Exacerbates the Need for Mental Illness Treatment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated pre-existing mental illness following long periods of isolation and uncertainty, driving patients to outpatient clinics for treatment for stressor-related disorders, anxiety and depression. A growing psychiatrist shortage strains the utilization of mental health clinics.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Federal Policies Could Extend the Coverage of Substance Abuse Treatment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Substance abuse programs provide a more affordable alternative to inpatient rehabilitation. Opioid misuse continues to rise, creating an unprecedented demand for substance abuse treatment.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Co-Occurring Disorders Treated at Inpatient Facilities Over Outpatient Clinics
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Treatment for co-occurring disorders (mental illness and substance use disorder) is referred to as integrated treatment. Individuals struggling with a co-occurring disorder are more likely to benefit from an inpatient program, pushing patients away from outpatient clinics.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As a central population hub, this area houses many mental health and substance abuse clinics to address the needs of its population. Florida has the most mental health and substance abuse clinics in the region.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of clinics mirrors its share of the population. Pennsylvania and New York contribute substantially to the share of clinics in this region. Densely populated cities in New York influence the number of mental health clinics in the state.

The West's share of mental health and substance abuse clinics falls closely in line with its share of the US population. The high concentration of clinics in the region is primarily a result of population distribution. California has the highest number of clinics in this region and the entire US.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Mental health and substance abuse clinics must prove a Certificate of Need (CON) before any construction, renovation or major medical equipment acquisitions. CONs are state regulatory mechanisms for healthcare facilities that determine the public need for a new facility or services. CON oversight exists to ensure health delivery services align with community needs to prevent heightened healthcare costs. CON violations can result in civil sanctions or revocation of a facility's license.

The Controlled Substances Act regulates medications used in medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid addiction. Substance abuse clinics must follow all drug policies regarding the acquisition, possession use and distribution of these controlled substances.
The Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act (CARA) outlines treatment and recovery responses for mental health and substance abuse clinics. CARA endorses the use of MAT for opioid use disorders.

Substance abuse clinics receive accreditation and certification for opioid treatment through the Certification of Opioid Treatment Programs. This certification outlines patient confidentiality, counseling and MAT requirements.

regulations_points.regulation_title: ANTI-KICKBACK STATUTE AND PHYSICIAN SELF-REFERRAL LAWS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) to induce the referral of business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs. Kickbacks promote overutilization of healthcare costs and corrupt decision-making by steering patients away from valid services. Physical self-referral law prohibits physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

regulations_points.regulation_title: HEALTH INSURANCE PORTABILITY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT
regulations_points.regulation_description: Mental health and substance abuse clinics must follow all of the criteria of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). HIPAA outlines controls for patient health data for any healthcare provider that stores, shares or sends private patient data.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Mental health clinics rely on qualified mental health professionals and nonclinical staff, facing rising wages and labor shortages.

basis_points.basis_description: Patients seek clinics with established histories of successful treatments.
Insurance limitations create steep out-of-pocket costs, so patients choose clinics balancing expenses and quality.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Mental health treatment delivery has historically been fragmented, with small independent clinics operating locally/regionally.
Certificate of Need laws in 36 states inhibit facility expansion, service additions and equipment purchases for clinics.
M&A activity, led by private equity, is consolidating the market as clinics seek growth in new markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages have ballooned to over half of industry revenue in recent years, with outpatient clinics designating an estimated 51.8% of earnings toward payroll expenses in 2023. Wages have grown faster than revenue has over the past five years. A shortfall of psychiatrists and an undersized mental health workforce pressures wage growth as clinics vie to attract and retain qualified clinical and non-clinical staff.

Profit accounts for an estimated 4.9% of revenue in 2023. Exact margins vary by organizational structure, treatment methods and tax designation (non-profit or for-profit clinics). Fluctuating reimbursement rates, wage growth and the COVID-19 pandemic have constrained profit growth in recent years, even as demand for comprehensive mental health treatment climbs to an all-time high.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Compliance and Legal Costs Are Steep
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs total an estimated 34.1% of revenue in 2023. Staying complicit with stringent federal and state regulations concerning billing, insurance, patient safety and data security adds considerable costs for clinics. Broadening adoption of IT solutions helps maintain clinics meet regulatory standards but adds to operating costs as clinics invest in cybersecurity systems, upgrades and IT professionals.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Mental health clinics rely on a staff of qualified mental health professionals and nonclinical employees. Since technology can't substitute for mental health treatment, new clinics will have to contend with rising wages and labor shortages to acquire staff. The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_title: No substitutes replicate outpatient mental health treatment
volatility_points.volatility_description: Mental health and substance abuse clinics provide essential treatment for individuals struggling with a mental illness, substance use disorder (SUD) or a co-occurring disorder. Outpatient treatment offers the most accessible form of care with limited substitutes, limiting volatility. Mental health conditions or substance use disorders can arise regardless of a person's employment status or economic standing, shielding the industry from volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Reliance on insurance reimbursements creates volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The extent of public and private insurance coverage of mental health treatment determines access to clinics. Reimbursements from payors also influence revenue for providers. Clinics' reliance on insurance providers introduces a degree of volatility to the industry. Treatment not covered by insurance turns into out-of-pocket costs for the patient. Individuals struggling with mental illness or SUD could defer treatment if they become worried about their ability to pay for treatment. A jump in the unemployment rate or economic uncertainty can strain a patient's ability to afford care.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Treatment for mental illness includes nonresidential treatment for any mental illness (AMI) or a serious mental illness (SMI). It excludes treatment for substance use disorder (SUD). Demand for outpatient treatment of mental illness has increased rapidly since COVID-19. The pandemic exacerbated preexisting mental illness following long periods of isolation and uncertainty, driving patients to outpatient clinics for treatment for stressor-related disorders, anxiety and depression.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Federal Policies Could Extend the Coverage of Substance Abuse Treatment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Treatment for substance abuse refers to nonresidential treatment for substance use disorder. It excludes treatment for mental illness. Substance abuse programs provide a more affordable alternative to inpatient rehabilitation. Patients receiving treatment for an alcohol-related SUD is the largest category in this segment. Outpatient programs tailored for substance abuse treatment typically offer a combination of individual and group counseling and other psychotherapy methods.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Co-occurring Disorders Treated at Inpatient Facilities Over Outpatient Clinics
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Treatment for co-occurring disorders includes nonresidential treatment for patients struggling with SUD and mental illness simultaneously. According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), people with mental health disorders are at a higher risk of developing SUD. Treatment for co-occurring disorders is referred to as integrated treatment, where practitioners address both mental and substance-use disorders at the same time.

FAQs.question: Has decreased private health coverage amid the coronavirus pandemic affected demand for your clinic?
FAQs.answer: Heightened unemployment has decreased private health coverage amid the coronavirus pandemic, amplifying industry reliance on government programs and out-of-pocket spending.

FAQs.question: What are the key points about the Anti-Kickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws?
FAQs.answer: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) to induce the referral of business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs. Kickbacks promote overutilization of healthcare costs and corrupt decision-making by steering patients away from valid services. Physical self-referral law prohibits physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

FAQs.question: What are the key requirements for mental health and substance abuse clinics under HIPAA?
FAQs.answer: Mental health and substance abuse clinics must follow all of the criteria of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). HIPAA outlines controls for patient health data for any healthcare provider that stores, shares or sends private patient data.

FAQs.question: What is the role of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI)?
FAQs.answer: The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) is a nonprofit organization providing advocacy, education, support and public awareness of mental health.

FAQs.question: How do profit margins fluctuate year-to-year for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: Margins depend on reimbursements from private and public insurers and out-of-pocket payments from patients. Changes to reimbursements from insurance providers affect a clinic's margin. For-profit clinics normally see a higher margin than not-for-profit clinics.

FAQs.question: What are some key points about operating costs and profitability for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: Wages are the primary expense for clinics. For nonprofit operators keeping operating costs down while providing high service levels is especially important since they generate lower revenue.

FAQs.question: Why is compliance with government regulations important for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: An inability to comply with government regulations may result in penalties, including loss of government program reimbursements or funding.

FAQs.question: What are some key factors affecting location and geographic reach for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: Facilities located close to referring doctors and highly populated cities are in a stronger position to attract clients. Low-income communities and rural communities are especially in need of mental health treatment.

FAQs.question: How important are donations and government funding for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: The ability to raise donations and obtain government funding is significant because these sources of funds make up large portions of total revenue.

FAQs.question: How does funding for SAMHSA affect demand for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: Increased funding for SAMHSA translates to higher funding for industry-relevant operators that participate in SAMHSA block programs.

FAQs.question: How does per capita disposable income affect demand for mental health clinics?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income rises, treatment services become more affordable to those who seek them, boosting demand for industry operators.
